title: 111_hr3954
content: The Act titled "Florida National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2010" releases deed restrictions on certain lands acquired under the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act in Florida. The Act releases deed restrictions on lands in Florida acquired under the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act, facilitating State forest management and reducing future Federal responsibilities. The Act releases deed restrictions on lands in Florida acquired under the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act, facilitating State forest management and reducing future Federal responsibilities. The Secretary shall release, convey, and quitclaim to the State of Florida, without monetary consideration, all rights, title, and remaining interest of the United States in lands within or adjacent to the Blackwater River and Withlacoochee State Forests. The conveyances are subject to terms and conditions, including the State covering reasonable costs incurred by the Secretary. The Secretary will cover reasonable costs for conveyances, including title searches and attorneys' fees. The State must use proceeds from property sales for land acquisition, resolve boundary encroachments, and indemnify the United States. The State must indemnify the United States for any boundary disputes related to parcels released under this section. SEC. 3. INTERCHANGE INVOLVING NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AND STATE LAND IN FLORIDA. The Congress finds intermingled Federal and State lands in Florida of comparable quantity and quality, which could be interchanged to facilitate more efficient public land management. "Approximately equal value" is defined as lands with similar physical characteristics and amenities. The State of Florida is authorized to offer land conveyance to the United States. The State of Florida offers to convey State lands designated for interchange to the United States. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey National Forest System lands in exchange. Maps of the designated lands will be available for public inspection for at least 5 years. Terms and conditions apply to the land interchange. The land interchange under this section is subject to terms and conditions agreed upon by the Secretary and the authorized officer of the State. If any designated lands are unsuitable for interchange due to various reasons, substitutions or modifications can be made as long as the lands are of comparable quality and value. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL LAND DISPOSAL UNDER FLORIDA NATIONAL FOREST LAND MANAGEMENT ACT OF 2003. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey a 114-acre parcel of land in Leon County, Florida, for sale or exchange. Proceeds from the sale will be used to acquire lands for the Apalachicola National Forest and cover disposal costs. The Secretary may use proceeds from the sale of certain tracts to acquire administrative improvements for National Forest units in Florida. The Act requires a designation in PAYGO Acts for budgetary effects to comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The statement must be submitted by the Chairman of the House Budget Committee before the vote on passage. Passed by the House of Representatives on March 17, 2010.
